info: Subscription revenue reported across several segments, with $290,000 for the most recent period and $10,000 for the prior year; newer periods show $280,000. Cash and cash equivalents total $280,000 as of 2025-11-28 and $290,000 as of 2024-11-29, matching the refundable customer deposits of $280,000.

Fair value of $796,343 reported for numerous Level 1‑3 securities (U.S. Treasury, corporate debt, money‑market, bank deposits, asset‑backed, government agency, foreign‑exchange contracts and interest‑rate swaps) with several designated as cash‑flow hedging instruments.

The filing outlines multiple debt arrangements, including repurchase authority periods, revolving credit facilities, and a series of notes with interest rates ranging from about 2.30% to 5.30% that mature in late 2024 and throughout 2025.

Adobe highlights its AI‑driven strategy targeting business, consumer, creative and marketing professionals, while noting its status as a large accelerated, well‑known seasoned issuer with a non‑affiliate market value of $144.94 billion and 410.5 million shares outstanding as of early 2026.

Adobe outlines a dual‑customer strategy targeting Business Professionals & Consumers and Creative & Marketing Professionals, emphasizing AI‑driven, integrated solutions such as Acrobat Studio, Firefly, GenStudio and Experience Platform. The company highlights expansion of AI agents, customizable models, and a broad partner ecosystem to deepen engagement, broaden geographic reach and differentiate amid intense competition across productivity, creative and marketing software markets.

Adobe will consolidate its three reportable segments into a single operating segment beginning Q1 FY2026, reflecting a strategic shift in resource allocation. The company highlighted its broad AI‑driven product portfolio across Digital Media and Digital Experience, ongoing R&D investments, and a focus on partner ecosystem. As of Nov 28 2025, Adobe employed 31,360 people with a 9.9% attrition rate and 78% employee engagement survey participation; the Learning Fund provides up to $11,000 per employee annually for education.

Adobe highlights its employee development programs, including a Learning Fund offering up to 11000 per year for education, internal job posting practices, and a focus on talent sharing. The filing also outlines material risk factors, notably challenges in innovating and competing in rapidly evolving AI-driven markets, potential reputational and regulatory risks from AI use, and intensified competition affecting pricing and margins.

The company faces material risks from evolving AI regulations, especially the EU AI Act (phased in through 2030), which could increase compliance, governance and R&D costs, expose it to fines, and require changes to business practices. Additional risks include liability from third‑party AI models, reputational harm, brand damage, integration challenges from acquisitions, talent recruitment and retention pressures, cybersecurity threats and potential service outages, and broader macro‑geopolitical and economic uncertainties.

The company highlights significant reliance on third‑party providers and multinational operations, exposing it to service interruptions, higher costs, and customer attrition if relationships falter. It faces broad macro‑economic, geopolitical and regulatory risks—including inflation, sanctions, data‑privacy laws, antitrust and emerging AI regulations—that could impede sales, increase compliance costs, and affect revenue. Extended enterprise sales cycles and complex contract negotiations may further raise expenses and delay revenue recognition. Additional concerns include intellectual‑property infringement, tax‑rate volatility, and government‑contract procurement challenges, all of which could negatively impact financial results.

The company faces multiple material risks including ongoing tax examinations, extensive government contract exposure with regulatory and procurement complexities, subscription revenue recognition lag that may delay impact of subscription changes, foreign currency volatility, potential goodwill or intangible impairment charges, and substantial debt obligations that could limit cash flow and covenant compliance. Additional concerns include stock price volatility, cybersecurity governance oversight, and large property footprints. Recent activity shows $6.15 billion senior unsecured notes, a $3 billion commercial paper program (no balances), a $1.5 billion undrawn revolving credit facility, and $25 billion authorized share repurchases. The company repurchased 7.2 million shares in Q4 2025 at average prices around $330‑$354, with approximately $21.8 billion of repurchase capacity remaining. It occupies about 1.7 million sq ft at its San Jose headquarters and 0.7 million sq ft each at its Bangalore and Noida sites, and had 801 record stockholders as of Jan 9 2026. Subscription terms range from 1 to 36 months.

Fiscal 2025 saw Adobe’s Digital Media ARR rise to $19.2bn (+11.5% YoY) and segment revenue to $17.65bn (+11%), while Digital Experience revenue grew 9% to $5.86bn; total Adobe ARR reached $25.2bn (+11.5%) and, after currency revaluation, $25.66bn. Net income jumped 28% to $7.13bn and cash flow from operations rose 25% to $10.03bn, while operating expenses were flat. Cost of revenue increased 8% to $2.55bn. Remaining performance obligations grew 13% to $22.52bn. The company highlighted AI‑infused product launches and a customer‑focused strategy, but noted exposure to macroeconomic inflation, interest rates and currency fluctuations.

Subscription revenue grew strongly in fiscal 2025, with Digital Media up $1.79 billion and Digital Experience up $498 million versus 2024, driven by Creative Cloud Pro, Acrobat and GenStudio solutions. Total subscription revenue reached $22.9 billion, up 12% YoY, and total revenue hit $23.8 billion, up 11% across all regions, with the Americas contributing the largest share. Currency effects lowered U.S.‑dollar revenue by $18 million but were offset by $22 million of hedging gains. Cost of revenue rose to $2.55 billion, led by higher subscription costs, while operating expenses increased to $12.51 billion, reflecting higher R&D, sales & marketing and modest G&A growth.

R&D and sales/marketing expenses rose in fiscal 2025, while general and administrative costs increased 3% driven by higher compensation, software licenses, consulting fees and lease impairments. The company recorded a $1 billion termination fee in fiscal 2024 from the aborted Figma deal. Interest expense jumped 56% to $263 million in 2025 due to new senior notes. Investment gains fell to $43 million and other income declined to $248 million. Provision for income taxes grew 17% to $1.604 billion, lowering the effective tax rate to 18% in 2025. A valuation allowance of $806 million and unrecognized tax liabilities of $693 million were reported. Cash and equivalents fell to $5.431 billion, with short‑term investments rising to $1.164 billion. Net cash from operations increased to $10.031 billion, but investing and financing activities used $1.187 billion and $11.060 billion respectively, resulting in a $2.182 billion net cash decrease. The company plans a cash‑financed acquisition of Semrush Holdings for approximately $1.9 billion in the first half of fiscal 2026.

Investors see substantial cash outflows in FY2025 with $11.06B financing use and $1.19B investing use, driven by $11.28B stock repurchases and a planned $1.9B Semrush acquisition financed largely by cash. The company maintains a $1.5B revolving credit line (potentially $2B) and $3B commercial paper capacity, while senior notes total $6.15B outstanding. Significant non‑cancellable purchase obligations of $6.82B and operating lease commitments of $485M exist. Foreign exchange contracts total $6.54B notional, with a $456M sensitivity to a 10% USD move. Short‑term investments of $1.16B are exposed to a $4M interest‑rate impact, and hedged fixed‑rate debt of $2.70B would change by $71M under a 50 bp rate shift.

Adobe reported higher revenue and net income in 2025 versus 2024, driven primarily by subscription growth, while total assets fell and total liabilities rose, resulting in a decline in stockholders' equity. Cash balances declined, long‑term debt increased, and treasury‑stock repurchases contributed to equity reduction.

Adobe’s equity base grew steadily from 2022 to 2025 with additional paid‑in capital rising from $9.9B to $15.4B and retained earnings climbing from $28.3B to $45.4B, while treasury‑stock balances deepened as the company accelerated share repurchases (‑$4.4B in 2022 to ‑$11.3B in 2025). Net income increased to $7.1B in 2025, supporting higher operating cash flow ($10.0B) but heavy financing outflows for stock buybacks reduced year‑end cash to $5.4B. The firm continued sizable stock‑based compensation (~$1.9B annually) and modest capital expenditures, while maintaining a strong cash generation profile.

Adobe’s notes describe revenue recognition centered on subscription and product sales, extensive reliance on estimates for allowances and tax provisions, advertising expenses increasing to $1.37 billion in FY2025, a 52‑week fiscal year pattern with a 53‑week year planned for FY2027, no finance leases, goodwill impairment tested qualitatively with quantitative analysis only if needed, capitalized contract costs amortized over five years, and active hedging of foreign‑currency exposures.

Revenue grew to $23.8B in FY2025, driven by Digital Media ($17.6B) and Digital Experience ($5.9B) with subscription revenue reaching $22.9B. The United States contributed $12.5B of the $14.1B Americas total. Deferred revenue rose to $7.03B and trade receivables to $2.34B, while the allowance for doubtful accounts stayed low at $13M. Recent accounting standard adoptions had no material impact and the company reports no significant credit concentration risk.

Deferred revenue grew to $7.03B as of November 28, 2025 (up from $6.26B in 2024) and includes $80M refundable deposits; $6.14B was recognized during the year. Remaining performance obligations stand at $22.52B, with about 65% expected to be recognized in the next 12 months. Capitalized contract acquisition costs were amortized $282M (2025), $272M (2024) and $254M (2023); the capitalized balance was $721M in 2025 and $717M in 2024, with $464M classified as long‑term. Refund liabilities were $137M (2025) and $141M (2024). Cash, cash equivalents and short‑term investments totaled $6.595B in 2025 versus $7.887B in 2024. Fair value of short‑term debt securities was $1.164B. Non‑cancellable, non‑refundable committed funds represent roughly 4% of both deferred revenue and remaining performance obligations.

The company reports fair‑value measurements for its financial assets, noting no credit‑loss allowance for fiscal 2025 and 2024. Its investment portfolio is high‑quality, AA‑rated, and classified as Level 2. Total assets rose to $6.404 billion at year‑end 2025, with $4.034 billion at Level 2. Cash‑flow hedge notional amounts increased to $5.97 billion in 2025 (vs $5.51 billion in 2024). Expected net derivative losses of $44 million will hit revenue, $5 million operating expense, and $3 million interest expense in the next 12 months.

The company entered $1 billion Treasury lock agreements in 2019 and currently faces $44 million of foreign‑currency cash‑flow hedge losses to be recognized in revenue, $5 million in operating expenses, and $3 million in interest expense over the next 12 months. It has $2.70 billion of interest‑rate swaps converting fixed senior‑note rates to floating SOFR, and foreign‑currency forward contracts with $563 million notional (2025) versus $381 million (2024). Fair‑value derivatives total $178 million (assets) and $108 million (liabilities) in 2025, with notable unrealized FX losses of $132 million. Reclassifications from OCI to income show modest impacts on revenue, operating and interest expense. Property and equipment net value is $1.873 billion (2025) with depreciation of $236 million. Operating lease expense declined to $92 million in 2025 after $117 million in 2023; a $78 million impairment was recorded in 2024. Lease liabilities total $485 million with a weighted‑average term of 6 years and 3.30% discount rate, and detailed maturities through 2030 are disclosed.

Lease liabilities total $485 million with a weighted‑average remaining term of 6 years and discount rate of 3.30%, scheduled $89 M due 2026 down to $57 M in 2030 and $93 M thereafter. Goodwill remained stable around $12.8 billion with no impairment. Other intangibles net $495 million; amortization expense $310 million in FY2025 (including $151 million in cost of sales) and expected $161‑65 million annually through 2030. Accrued and other current liabilities rose to $2.648 billion, driven by compensation ($1.345 billion) and marketing ($197 million). Income before tax increased to $8.734 billion in FY2025, up from $6.799 billion in FY2023, with domestic earnings driving the growth. Provision for income taxes was $1.604 billion in FY2025, comprising $2.118 billion current and –$0.514 billion deferred components.

Deferred tax assets increased to 2155 million net in 2025 from 1626 million in 2024, with a valuation allowance of 806 million. Federal and state tax credit carryforwards stand at 146 million and 412 million, and capital loss carryforwards total 1130 million. Unrecognized tax benefit balances rose modestly, ending at 693 million, and management notes a possible 40 million reduction in the next year. Retirement plan contributions rose to 96 million in 2025. Deferred compensation invested amounts grew to 342 million, with undistributed balances of 354 million. Stock‑based compensation reserves include 76.0 million shares under the 2019 plan and 103.0 million ESPP shares. RSU and performance share balances and fair values are disclosed, with RSUs ending at 7.9 million shares (2532 million aggregate) and performance shares at 0.6 million shares (183 million aggregate).

Compensation awards showed higher grant‑date fair values in 2024, with vested fair values of $49M (2025), $63M (2024) and $39M (2023). The Employee Stock Purchase Plan saw purchases of about 1.1‑1.2 million shares each year, generating intrinsic values up to $324M in 2024. Unrecognized compensation cost stood at $3.24 billion, to be recognized over 2.19 years. Stock‑based compensation expense was $1.94 billion in 2025 with tax benefits of $262 million. Net income increased to $7.13 billion in 2025, yielding basic EPS of $16.73. Share repurchases in 2025 delivered 30.8 million shares for $11.3 billion, while $5.9 billion remains under the $25 billion repurchase authority. Unconditional purchase obligations total $6.821 billion through 2030. Adobe announced a $1.9 billion cash acquisition of Semrush expected to close in early FY2026, and royalty expense was $283 million in 2025.

Adobe faces multiple ongoing legal matters, including FTC/DOJ enforcement actions over subscription disclosures, a securities class action and several shareholder derivative suits, with no quantifiable loss estimate available. Debt remains substantial, with approximately $6.21 bn of long‑term debt and $1.50 bn of current debt outstanding as of Nov 28 2025, comprised of various senior notes across 2025‑2035 maturities. The company issued $2.0 bn of senior notes in early 2025, repaid $1.5 bn in February 2025, and maintains an undrawn $1.5 bn revolving credit facility (expandable to $2 bn) and a $3 bn commercial paper program.

The company had no outstanding borrowings on its revolving credit facility or commercial paper program as of November 28, 2025, while maintaining a $3 billion commercial paper capacity. Non‑operating results show interest expense of $263 million, $169 million and $113 million for 2025‑2023 respectively, interest income of $264 million, $341 million and $269 million, realized investment gains of $16 million, $12 million and $6 million, unrealized gains of $27 million, $36 million and $10 million, and net non‑operating income of $28 million, $190 million and $149 million for the same years. The audit highlighted effective internal controls and identified a critical audit matter concerning subscription revenue of $17.39 billion recorded in the Digital Media segment.

Adobe references its insider trading policy and notes that executive compensation, security ownership, related transactions, director independence, and principal accountant fees are incorporated by reference to the 2026 Proxy Statement. The exhibits list includes the merger agreement, corporate certificates, bylaws, and multiple debt indentures and note series.

The filing lists multiple exhibits, including performance share award notices for 2024‑2025, restricted stock unit grants, indemnity agreements, credit agreements and executive compensation plans, indicating continued equity incentive programs and financing arrangements.
The Form 10‑K was signed on January 15 2026 by CEO Shantanu Narayen, CFO Daniel Durn, and other directors.
